title: The Tortoise and the Hare
summary: A speedy hare challenges a steady tortoise and learns that bragging can trip you up.
imageAlt: Stylized tortoise and hare lining up on a racetrack.
author: Jacob Sutanto
body: The forest animals gathered for a race. The hare bounced with energy and bragged that he would win by a mile.
The tortoise stretched his neck and nodded. "I may be slow," he said, "but I never give up."
When the race began, the hare zipped ahead. Soon he grew bored. He took a nap under a shady tree.
The tortoise moved at a steady pace. Step by careful step, he passed the sleeping hare and reached the finish line first.
The hare woke up too late. "How did I lose?" he cried. The tortoise smiled. "Fast feet are nice, but steady steps win the race."

questions.prompt: Why did the forest animals gather together?
options: To cheer for a race between the hare and the tortoise
questions.explanation: The animals came to watch the hare race the tortoise.

questions.prompt: The tortoise promised, 'I may be slow, but I never ______.'
questions.explanation: The tortoise believed steady effort would help him finish the race.

questions.prompt: What did the hare do after racing ahead of the tortoise?
options: He stopped to take a nap under a tree.
He helped the tortoise run faster.
questions.explanation: The hare became bored, stopped, and fell asleep.

questions.prompt: Match each character or idea with the correct description.

answer.d: Slow and steady wins the race

Hare took a nap under a tree

questions.prompt: Which character trait helped the tortoise win?

questions.prompt: The tortoise reminded the hare that steady steps ______ the race.

questions.prompt: What did the hare learn when he woke up?
options: He lost because he was too confident and took a nap.
He lost because the tortoise asked for help.
He lost because the race was cancelled.
questions.explanation: The hare realized bragging and resting cost him the race.

questions.prompt: What is the fable warning readers about?
acceptableAnswers: It warns against bragging and teaches that steady effort is stronger than showing off.
The story tells us not to be overconfident and to keep working steadily.
questions.explanation: The fable encourages humility and persistence instead of bragging.

questions.prompt: How might the race change if the hare encouraged the tortoise instead of bragging?
options: They might cheer each other on and finish proudly together.
The tortoise would refuse to race at all.
The hare would forget how to run.
questions.explanation: Encouragement could turn the race into a friendly challenge instead of a bragging contest.
